metadata.subject: chemistry
metadata.dotPoint: The distinction between reversible and irreversible reactions, and between rate and extent of a reaction

reversible_reaction.name: Reversible Reaction
reversible_reaction.correct: A reversible reaction can proceed in BOTH directions: reactants form products (forward) AND products reform reactants (reverse). Both reactions occur simultaneously.

can be stopped and started again.error: That's not what 'reversible' means in chemistry.
can be stopped and started again.fix: Reversible means the reaction runs in BOTH directions at once, not that you can pause it.
can be stopped and started again.action: Think of reversible as 'two-way traffic', not 'pause button'.

goes completely to products then back.error: Both directions occur simultaneously, not sequentially.
goes completely to products then back.fix: Forward and reverse reactions happen at the same time, not one after the other.
goes completely to products then back.action: At any moment, some reactants are becoming products while some products become reactants.

only occurs with a catalyst.error: Catalysts are not required for reversibility.
only occurs with a catalyst.fix: Many reactions are naturally reversible. Catalysts speed up both directions but don't create reversibility.
only occurs with a catalyst.action: Nâ‚‚Oâ‚„ â‡Œ 2NOâ‚‚ is reversible without any catalyst.

persistent.gap: You're confusing chemical reversibility with everyday uses of 'reversible'.
persistent.action: Define: reversible reaction = forward and reverse reactions occur simultaneously.

irreversible_reaction.name: Irreversible Reaction
irreversible_reaction.correct: An irreversible reaction proceeds in ONE direction only. Products cannot react to reform the original reactants under normal conditions.

can be reversed with enough energy.error: Under normal conditions, the reverse reaction doesn't occur.
can be reversed with enough energy.fix: Combustion, cooking, and many other reactions are practically irreversible.
can be reversed with enough energy.action: You can't 'unburn' wood or 'uncook' an egg.

reaches equilibrium eventually.error: Irreversible reactions go to completion, not equilibrium.
reaches equilibrium eventually.fix: All reactants are converted to products. No equilibrium mixture forms.
reaches equilibrium eventually.action: Combustion continues until fuel runs outâ€”no reverse reaction.

is slower than reversible reactions.error: Reversibility has nothing to do with speed.
is slower than reversible reactions.fix: Irreversible reactions can be fast or slow. Combustion is fast and irreversible.
is slower than reversible reactions.action: Rate (speed) and reversibility are independent properties.

persistent.gap: You think irreversibility is about difficulty rather than directionality.
persistent.action: Give 3 examples of irreversible reactions. Explain why the reverse doesn't occur.

forward_reverse_reactions.name: Forward and Reverse Reactions
forward_reverse_reactions.formula: Forward: A â†’ B, Reverse: B â†’ A
forward_reverse_reactions.correct: In a reversible reaction, the forward reaction converts reactants to products, while the reverse reaction converts products back to reactants. Both occur simultaneously.

occur one at a time.error: Forward and reverse reactions occur simultaneously.
occur one at a time.fix: At any moment, molecules are reacting in both directions. It's continuous.
occur one at a time.action: Like people entering and leaving a building at the same time.

forward always dominates.error: Either direction can dominate depending on conditions.
forward always dominates.fix: Position of equilibrium determines which direction is favoured.
forward always dominates.action: High K means products favoured; low K means reactants favoured.

reverse only starts after forward finish.error: Both start immediately when reactants are present.
reverse only starts after forward finish.fix: As soon as products form, the reverse reaction begins.
reverse only starts after forward finish.action: There's never a time when only one direction is occurring.

persistent.gap: You see forward and reverse as sequential rather than simultaneous.
persistent.action: Draw arrows showing both directions happening at the same time in a single system.

equilibrium_symbol.name: Equilibrium Symbol
equilibrium_symbol.correct: Reversible reactions are represented using the equilibrium symbol â‡Œ (two half-arrows pointing in opposite directions), showing that both forward and reverse reactions occur.

single arrow â†’.error: A single arrow indicates an irreversible reaction.
single arrow â†’.fix: Use â‡Œ for reversible reactions to show both directions.
single arrow â†’.action: â†’ means one-way only. â‡Œ means two-way (reversible).

double-headed arrow â†”.error: â†” is used for resonance structures, not equilibrium.
double-headed arrow â†”.fix: The equilibrium symbol has two HALF-arrows: â‡Œ
double-headed arrow â†”.action: â‡Œ shows forward and reverse reactions. â†” shows resonance.

equals sign =.error: An equals sign doesn't show reaction direction.
equals sign =.fix: Chemical equations use arrows to show transformation, not equals signs.
equals sign =.action: â‡Œ shows dynamic process; = would suggest static equality.

persistent.gap: You confuse the equilibrium symbol with other chemical notation.
persistent.action: Draw: â†’ (irreversible), â‡Œ (equilibrium), â†” (resonance). Label each.

rate_of_reaction.name: Rate of Reaction
rate_of_reaction.correct: Rate of reaction measures the SPEED at which reactants are consumed or products are formed. It tells you HOW FAST the reaction proceeds.

how much product forms.fix: Rate is about SPEED (how fast). Extent is about AMOUNT (how much).
how much product forms.action: A fast car (high rate) doesn't necessarily travel far (extent).

the position of equilibrium.error: Rate and equilibrium position are different concepts.
the position of equilibrium.fix: Rate = speed of reaction. Equilibrium position = relative amounts at equilibrium.
the position of equilibrium.action: A catalyst increases rate but doesn't change equilibrium position.

whether the reaction is reversible.fix: Both reversible and irreversible reactions have rates. They're independent properties.
whether the reaction is reversible.action: A slow reaction can be reversible; a fast reaction can be irreversible.

persistent.gap: You confuse rate (speed) with other reaction properties.
persistent.action: Complete: Rate tells you HOW ___. Extent tells you HOW ___.

extent_of_reaction.name: Extent of Reaction
extent_of_reaction.formula: Extent = degree of completion towards products
extent_of_reaction.correct: Extent of reaction measures the DEGREE to which a reaction proceeds towards completion. It tells you HOW MUCH reactants have been converted to products.

how fast the reaction occurs.fix: Extent is about HOW MUCH conversion. Rate is about HOW FAST.
how fast the reaction occurs.action: A reaction can go far (high extent) slowly (low rate) or vice versa.

the speed of reaching equilibrium.error: Speed to equilibrium is still about rate, not extent.
the speed of reaching equilibrium.fix: Extent describes WHERE equilibrium lies (products vs reactants favoured).
the speed of reaching equilibrium.action: High extent = mostly products. Low extent = mostly reactants.

only applies to reversible reactions.fix: Irreversible reactions typically go to completion (100% extent).
only applies to reversible reactions.action: Extent applies to all reactionsâ€”it's just often 100% for irreversible ones.

persistent.action: State: Extent = how FAR the reaction goes. Rate = how FAST it gets there.

rate_extent_independence.name: Rate and Extent Are Independent
rate_extent_independence.correct: Rate and extent are INDEPENDENT properties. A reaction can be fast but not go far (high rate, low extent) or slow but go nearly to completion (low rate, high extent).

fast reactions go further.error: Speed doesn't determine how far a reaction goes.
fast reactions go further.fix: Rate (kinetics) and extent (thermodynamics) are governed by different factors.
fast reactions go further.action: A catalyst increases rate but doesn't change extent.

they measure the same thing differently.fix: Rate = speed of change. Extent = degree of completion. Separate concepts.
they measure the same thing differently.action: Like speed of a car vs distance travelledâ€”related but different.

high rate means high extent.fix: A reaction can be fast but reach equilibrium with mostly reactants, or slow but favour products.
high rate means high extent.action: Catalysts increase rate without changing extent (equilibrium position).

persistent.gap: You think rate and extent are correlated.
persistent.action: Give an example of: high rate + low extent, and low rate + high extent.

closed_system.name: Closed System Requirement
closed_system.correct: For a reversible reaction to reach equilibrium, it must occur in a CLOSED system where no reactants or products can enter or escape.

open system.error: In open systems, products escape before reverse reaction can occur.
open system.fix: Closed systems trap everything, allowing forward and reverse reactions to balance.
open system.action: An open beaker lets gases escape; a sealed flask keeps them inside.

isolated system.error: Isolated means no energy transfer eitherâ€”that's more restrictive.
isolated system.fix: Closed = no matter exchange. Energy can still flow (e.g., heating).
isolated system.action: A sealed flask you can heat is closed but not isolated.

any system.error: Equilibrium specifically requires a closed system.
any system.fix: Open systems allow products to escape, preventing equilibrium.
any system.action: Combustion in open air is irreversible because products disperse.

persistent.gap: You don't understand why system boundaries matter for equilibrium.
persistent.action: Explain: Why can't an open beaker of boiling water reach equilibrium?

dynamic_equilibrium_intro.name: Dynamic Equilibrium Introduction
dynamic_equilibrium_intro.formula: Forward rate = Reverse rate, concentrations constant
dynamic_equilibrium_intro.correct: At dynamic equilibrium, forward and reverse reactions occur at EQUAL RATES, so concentrations remain CONSTANT. The system is dynamic (reactions continue) but appears static.

reactions have stopped.error: 'Dynamic' specifically means reactions are still occurring.
reactions have stopped.fix: Both reactions continue at equal rates. Concentrations don't change because rates balance.
reactions have stopped.action: Like water level in a bathtub with equal inflow and outflowâ€”level constant, flow continues.

concentrations are equal.error: Concentrations are CONSTANT, not necessarily EQUAL.
concentrations are equal.fix: Reactant and product concentrations stay the same but can be very different from each other.
concentrations are equal.action: A reaction favouring products has more products than reactants at equilibrium.

only forward reaction occurs.error: Both forward and reverse reactions occur at equilibrium.
only forward reaction occurs.fix: Equal rates of forward and reverse reactions = dynamic equilibrium.
only forward reaction occurs.action: The â‡Œ symbol reminds us both directions are active.

persistent.gap: You think equilibrium means reactions have stopped or concentrations are equal.
persistent.action: State the two key features: equal rates AND constant (not equal) concentrations.

equilibrium_mixture.name: Equilibrium Mixture
equilibrium_mixture.correct: At equilibrium, BOTH reactants AND products are present in the mixture. Reversible reactions never go to 100% completion.

only products remain.error: That would be an irreversible reaction.
only products remain.fix: Reversible reactions always have both reactants and products at equilibrium.
only products remain.action: If all reactants were gone, there could be no reverse reaction.

equal amounts of each.error: The amounts depend on the equilibrium constant, not a 50-50 split.
equal amounts of each.fix: Position of equilibrium determines the ratio, which can heavily favour one side.
equal amounts of each.action: K >> 1 means mostly products. K << 1 means mostly reactants.

reactants are used up first.error: Equilibrium is reached before reactants are used up.
reactants are used up first.fix: As products form, the reverse reaction begins, establishing equilibrium.
reactants are used up first.action: The mixture stabilises with both species present.

persistent.gap: You expect complete conversion in all reactions.
persistent.action: Explain why reversible reactions can never reach 100% products.

position_of_equilibrium.name: Position of Equilibrium
position_of_equilibrium.formula: Relative amounts of products vs reactants
position_of_equilibrium.correct: The position of equilibrium describes whether products or reactants are favoured at equilibrium. A position 'to the right' favours products; 'to the left' favours reactants.

how fast equilibrium is reached.fix: Position tells you WHERE equilibrium lies, not how quickly you get there.
how fast equilibrium is reached.action: Catalysts affect rate (speed) but not position (where you end up).

the midpoint of the reaction.error: Equilibrium isn't necessarily at the midpoint.
the midpoint of the reaction.fix: Position can be far to the right (mostly products) or left (mostly reactants).
the midpoint of the reaction.action: K value tells you: K >> 1 = right, K << 1 = left.

when reactions stop.fix: Position describes the stable concentrations, not a stopping point.
when reactions stop.action: Reactions continue; position describes the constant ratio achieved.

persistent.gap: You confuse equilibrium position with rate or with reactions stopping.
persistent.action: Define: Position = ratio of products to reactants at equilibrium.

reversible_reaction.title: Reversible Reactions
reversible_reaction.content: A reversible reaction can proceed in both directions simultaneously. Reactants form products (forward reaction) while products reform reactants (reverse reaction). This is represented by the equilibrium symbol â‡Œ.
keyPoints: Uses â‡Œ symbol, not single arrow
Can reach equilibrium in closed systems

irreversible_reaction.title: Irreversible Reactions
irreversible_reaction.content: An irreversible reaction proceeds in one direction only. Products cannot react to reform the original reactants under normal conditions. These reactions go to completion rather than reaching equilibrium.

forward_reverse_reactions.title: Forward and Reverse Reactions
forward_reverse_reactions.content: In a reversible reaction, the forward reaction converts reactants to products while the reverse reaction converts products back to reactants. Both occur continuously once the reaction begins.
keyPoints: At equilibrium, both continue at equal rates

equilibrium_symbol.title: The Equilibrium Symbol
equilibrium_symbol.content: The equilibrium symbol â‡Œ consists of two half-arrows pointing in opposite directions, indicating that both forward and reverse reactions occur. This distinguishes reversible reactions from irreversible ones (â†’).

rate_of_reaction.title: Rate of Reaction
rate_of_reaction.content: Rate of reaction measures the speed at which reactants are consumed or products are formed. It tells you how fast the reaction proceeds, typically expressed as change in concentration per unit time.
keyPoints: Units: mol Lâ»Â¹ sâ»Â¹ or similar

extent_of_reaction.title: Extent of Reaction
extent_of_reaction.content: Extent of reaction measures the degree to which a reaction proceeds towards completion. It tells you how much of the reactants have been converted to products at a given point in time.

rate_extent_independence.title: Independence of Rate and Extent
rate_extent_independence.content: Rate and extent are independent properties. A reaction can be fast but not go far (high rate, low extent) or slow but nearly complete (low rate, high extent). Catalysts demonstrate this by increasing rate without changing extent.
keyPoints: Catalysts increase rate but not extent

closed_system.title: Closed System Requirement
closed_system.content: For a reversible reaction to reach equilibrium, it must occur in a closed system where no matter can enter or escape. In open systems, products can escape before the reverse reaction occurs.

dynamic_equilibrium_intro.title: Dynamic Equilibrium
dynamic_equilibrium_intro.content: At dynamic equilibrium, forward and reverse reactions occur at equal rates, so concentrations remain constant. The system is 'dynamic' because reactions continue, but appears static because no net change occurs.

equilibrium_mixture.title: Equilibrium Mixture
equilibrium_mixture.content: At equilibrium, both reactants and products are present in the mixture. Reversible reactions never go to 100% completion because the reverse reaction always reforms some reactants.

position_of_equilibrium.title: Position of Equilibrium
position_of_equilibrium.content: The position of equilibrium describes whether products or reactants are favoured in the equilibrium mixture. 'Position to the right' means mostly products; 'position to the left' means mostly reactants.
keyPoints: Can be shifted by changing conditions
